segments.en: Numbered Discourses 3
4. Messengers of the Gods
39. A Delicate Lifestyle
“My lifestyle was delicate, mendicants, most delicate, extremely delicate.

segments.pli: Mama sudaṃ, bhikkhave, pitu nivesane pokkharaṇiyo kāritā honti.
segments.en: In my father’s house, lotus ponds were made just for me.

segments.pli: Ekattha sudaṃ, bhikkhave, uppalaṃ vappati, ekattha padumaṃ, ekattha puṇḍarīkaṃ, yāvadeva mamatthāya.
segments.en: In some, blue water lilies blossomed, while in others, there were pink or white lotuses, just for my benefit.

segments.pli: Na kho panassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, akāsikaṃ candanaṃ dhāremi. Kāsikaṃ, bhikkhave, su me taṃ veṭhanaṃ hoti, kāsikā kañcukā, kāsikaṃ nivāsanaṃ, kāsiko uttarāsaṅgo.
segments.en: I only used sandalwood from Kāsī, and my turbans, jackets, sarongs, and upper robes also came from Kāsī.

segments.pli: Rattindivaṃ kho pana me su taṃ, bhikkhave, setacchattaṃ dhārīyati:
segments.en: And a white parasol was held over me night and day, with the thought:

segments.pli: ‘mā naṃ phusi sītaṃ vā uṇhaṃ vā tiṇaṃ vā rajo vā ussāvo vā’ti.
segments.en: ‘Don’t let cold, heat, grass, dust, or damp bother him.’

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, tayo pāsādā ahesuṃ—eko hemantiko, eko gimhiko, eko vassiko.
segments.en: I had three stilt longhouses—one for the winter, one for the summer, and one for the rainy season.

segments.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, vassike pāsāde vassike cattāro māse nippurisehi tūriyehi paricārayamāno na heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ orohāmi.
segments.en: I stayed in a stilt longhouse without coming downstairs for the four months of the rainy season, where I was entertained by musicians—none of them men.

segments.pli: Yathā kho pana, bhikkhave, aññesaṃ nivesane dāsakammakaraporisassa kaṇājakaṃ bhojanaṃ dīyati bilaṅgadutiyaṃ, evamevassu me, bhikkhave, pitu nivesane dāsakammakaraporisassa sālimaṃsodano dīyati.
segments.en: While the bondservants, workers, and staff in other houses are given rough gruel with pickles to eat, in my father’s house they eat fine rice with meat.

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, evarūpāya iddhiyā samannāgatassa evarūpena ca sukhumālena etadahosi:
segments.en: Amid such prosperity and such a delicate lifestyle, I thought:

segments.pli: ‘assutavā kho puthujjano attanā jarādhammo samāno jaraṃ anatīto paraṃ jiṇṇaṃ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṃyeva atisitvā, ahampi khomhi jarādhammo jaraṃ anatīto.
segments.en: ‘When an uneducated ordinary person—who is liable to grow old, not being exempt from old age—sees someone else who is old, they’re horrified, repelled, and disgusted, overlooking the fact that they themselves are in the same situation.

segments.pli: Ahañceva kho pana jarādhammo samāno jaraṃ anatīto paraṃ jiṇṇaṃ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṃ harāyeyyaṃ jiguccheyyaṃ na metaṃ assa patirūpan’ti.
segments.en: But since I, too, am liable to grow old, it would not be appropriate for me to be horrified, embarrassed, and disgusted, when I see someone else who is old.’

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo yobbane yobbanamado so sabbaso pahīyi.
segments.en: Reflecting like this, I entirely gave up the vanity of youth.

segments.pli: Assutavā kho puthujjano attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhiṃ anatīto paraṃ byādhitaṃ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṃyeva atisitvā:
segments.en: ‘When an uneducated ordinary person—who is liable to get sick, not being exempt from sickness—sees someone else who is sick, they’re horrified, repelled, and disgusted, overlooking the fact that they themselves are in the same situation.

segments.pli: ‘ahampi khomhi byādhidhammo byādhiṃ anatīto, ahañceva kho pana byādhidhammo samāno byādhiṃ anatīto paraṃ byādhikaṃ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṃ harāyeyyaṃ jiguccheyyaṃ, na metaṃ assa patirūpan’ti.
segments.en: But since I, too, am liable to get sick, it would not be appropriate for me to be horrified, embarrassed, and disgusted, when I see someone else who is sick.’

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo ārogye ārogyamado so sabbaso pahīyi.
segments.en: Reflecting like this, I entirely gave up the vanity of health.

segments.pli: Assutavā kho puthujjano attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇaṃ anatīto paraṃ mataṃ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṃyeva atisitvā:
segments.en: ‘When an uneducated ordinary person—who is liable to die, not being exempt from death—sees someone else who is dead, they’re horrified, repelled, and disgusted, overlooking the fact that they themselves are in the same situation.

segments.pli: ‘ahampi khomhi maraṇadhammo, maraṇaṃ anatīto, ahaṃ ceva kho pana maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇaṃ anatīto paraṃ mataṃ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṃ harāyeyyaṃ jiguccheyyaṃ, na metaṃ assa patirūpan’ti.
segments.en: But since I, too, am liable to die, it would not be appropriate for me to be horrified, embarrassed, and disgusted, when I see someone else who is dead.’

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo jīvite jīvitamado so sabbaso pahīyīti.
segments.en: Reflecting like this, I entirely gave up the vanity of life.
There are these three vanities.
What three?
The vanity of youth, of health, and of life.

segments.pli: Yobbanamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
segments.en: Intoxicated with the vanity of youth, an uneducated ordinary person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

segments.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
segments.en: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

segments.pli: Ārogyamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano … pe …
segments.en: Intoxicated with the vanity of health …

segments.pli: jīvitamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
segments.en: Intoxicated with the vanity of life, an uneducated ordinary person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

segments.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
segments.en: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

segments.pli: Yobbanamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
segments.en: Intoxicated with the vanity of youth, health, or life, a mendicant rejects the training and returns to a lesser life.

segments.pli: jīvitamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattatīti.

segments.en: For others, sickness is natural,
and so are old age and death.
Though this is how their nature is,
ordinary people feel disgusted.
If I were to be disgusted
with creatures whose nature is such,
it would not be appropriate for me,
since my life is just the same.
Living in such a way,
I understood the reality without attachments.
I mastered all vanities—
of health, of youth,
and even of life—
seeing safety in renunciation.
Zeal sprang up in me
as I looked to extinguishment.
Now I’m unable
to indulge in sensual pleasures;
there’s no turning back,
until the spiritual life is complete.”
